answers.answer: Perhaps you should see a competent endocrinoligist - which is not your current doctor, and take in copies of your current testing, and get more testing, and find out what is really going on.It may be that you have more health issues going on.As well, consuming too few calories is also detrimental - the body will not lose when it is starving so make sure you are dieting well. I would eat more small meals then two meals as that would raise your blood sugar and be very bad for  your diabetes - you need to eat for that. So eat more often, eating less. Going without meals with make the diabetes worse.Central weight gain is often cortisol - any testing on that?

I totally agree w/rumpled.  I have Hashimoto's also, and gained a ridiculous amt of weight...exercise...'dieting' etc. did nothing.Since I was diagnosed w/Adrenal Insufficiency, [low cortisol]  my weight has been dropping slowly, steadily.  At one time I was up to 230lbs [at 5/6"]  ached all over, was extremely fatigued.  When cortisol was added to the mix of meds, many of my other health issues have dropped by the wayside also.Please, see an endo!  If your thyroid is adjusted according to what 'normal' range, and you're still feeling lousy, ask for a cortisol level test.  [be careful, though, many docs don't like the patient so suggest tests...it wounds their ego]  I've also been diagnosed w/Fibromyalglia, and suffered for years.  Since starting the cortisol replacement [Jan of this year] the aches have lessened and I can function.  I still have the tender points but it's much better all around.Also, rumpled is correct...the ramifications of too few calories can be detrimental to your entire well-being.  It's ok to limit some things, but not to cut calories to the point that your body is living off itself.

Hi again!Just a little abt cortisol.  It's a hormone released by your adrenal glands when under stress.  Stress can be anything from doing too much, having all sorts of problems, and health issues. I was hypothyroid for abt 30 years; then I needed back surgery...I had 4 surgeries over 5 years.  That put a lot of stress on my body, I slowly depleted my cortisol, and weight piled on with vengence.  I became increasingly fatigued, hardly ate a thing [I was too exhausted to eat] but the weight just kept rising.  Last year, May 30, my husband passed away and added more stress.  I was disabled from the surgeries, constantly fatigued,  and gained even more weight.  Finally, in Jan I told my doc "Something HAS to be wrong...I can't go on living like this".  She thought a minute, and said "I don't know....I wonder if we should check your cortisol".  Not knowing what cortisol is, I still jumped in, "YES!"...my thought being....try something different, all the other tests came back 'normal'.  I was tested 2 weeks later.  They found I was WAY low...almost non-existant.I returned to her, and she put me on hydrocortisone, a hormone that replaces what the adrenal gland doesn't.  Within 3 days I noticed I was energetic, and could walk better.  She had me on a high dose to 'jump start' my adrenals.  Three weeks later, and one more visit to her, she cut me back...I still did well.  The only thing my endo did was to change my thyroid dose to 112mcg [which for me is quite minimal]  According to the thyro test I was running 'hyper'. Well, I have no symptoms of hyperthyroidism, except the weight loss.  I'm to be checked next week, and see the endo on the 29th.  If she wants to lower my dosage, I am going to refuse.  It's my belief that doctors shouldn't go according to what's 'normal'.  They should include the symptoms...if a person is within 'normal' range, but feeling fatigued and maintaining/gaining a large amt of weight, that should be factored in, and the dosage should be raised.  Docs seem to just go by what the books say, and don't listen to the patients.  In my case, they were giving me all kinds of meds to 'change the symptoms'.  That didn't work; all that happened was I had a lot of drugs inside me, and a thinner wallet.  I'm now off 5 of the medications, and only taking Synthoid [she wouldn't allow me to take levothyroxine as I did for over 40 years]  and Hydrocortisone, 5mg...10mg in the morning, 5mg in the afternoon, no later than 4.  [too much cortisol can keep a person from sleeping]Well, that's my story and explanation.Are you under more stress than usual?  Do you have body aches/pains?  Many doctors say 'it's just stress'.  Well, DUH...they don't think further to say.."Hmmmm...maybe this person's cortisol is low".Please let me know what happens at your visit to the endo...I'm really concerned.  I'll also let you know what happens at MY endo appt. the 29th.My best to you.
I forgot to tell you....when you google cortisol, also google Adrenal Insufficiency....unless your google already refers to it.....I'm thinking this may possibly be your problem.

Hi there -I'm glad I found this thread.  As I suspect is the case for a few others here, I have Schmidt's Syndrome - I've been a Type I Diabetic for 21 years and was just diagnosed in February with Addison's and Hashimoto's Diseases (or the Schmidt's Trifecta, as I refer to it).  My thyroid function is still normal (lab results from two weeks ago showed T4 Since going on hydrocortisone, my weight has increased dramatically - going from 170lbs around March 1st to 200lbs this month.  To try to quell this, we're slightly cutting back my hydrocortisone dosage, and I also just started taking DHEA (levels were low in my labs).  This may help to at least stop the weight GAIN, but I believe the lower hydrocortisone dose is leading to more persistent shortness of breath over the last few days.  Needless to say, it's frustrating, as are so many things when trying to manually balance the very delicate endocrine system!Anyway, I'd love to hear from anyone who has experienced similar symptoms with Addison's or other adrenal insufficiency, how you've dealt with it, etc.Thanks in advance for your responses!

First of all, in all circumstances - no disease has a perfect sign and with high and low cortisol, there are so many symptoms, no one person has all of them.I used to have high cortisol, and now I have low since my adrenals were removed to cure the high cortisol - so I have lived both. The flush, BTW, is HIGH cortisol. And she is sort of describing a moon face, again a high cortisol symptom. I never got that either - it is set on charts as 20%.
